title_sort: hannah whitman heyde to walt whitman, 18 april [1889]
title: Hannah Whitman Heyde to Walt Whitman, 18 April [1889]
text: Burlington Vt.April 18Thursday Afternoon89I do hope my dearest brother you are feeling a good deal better to day & do want you to be so much. my greatest comfort is thinking about your being pretty well comfortable.You never complain are always patient Walt dear & an example for us all.You are more than kind to write me such a long letter when you are not strong. I am so sick (and I do feel so sorry) is all the rest in the letter. Every word good to know.I think of you always my dear brother, as I always like to tell you indeed Walt & dont think I could live with out thinking about you—I mean you are so good to me and it is so good to have you to think of.Walt dear if I could only write something cheerful, if I only could do anything for you—could see youEveryone I know asks after you Mrs Tyler always & all her children, & Mrs Griswold never failsI do feel your sending me this money Walt—you have sent me so much before, of course I should not have so many things my cloak for instance I must tell you again Walt you are first firstI have been working around this morning getting dinner & so on wanted to write anyway a line or two.I am going to think you are better yet to day, your letter was written two days ago, I thank you very much for writing. I had not heard you was sick my dear brotherIt is right pretty to hear about those wild flowers.—Walt dear I send love with all my heartHanLove to Lou & George and Edy Hannah Whitman Heyde to Walt Whitman, 18 April [1889]
